choices.text: Chronic lung condition due to prematurity

questions.text: Which of the following is not a known risk factor for bronchiolitis in an infant?
questions.solution:
RISK FACTORS FOR BRONCHIOLITIS

  • Parents who smoke
  • Siblings attending day care or school (risk of transmitting viral infections)
  • Chronic lung disease due to prematurity
  • Breastfeeding given for <2 months

questions.text: A 2-year-old child born abroad presents to the GP with another chest infection: this has been his 3rd infection this winter requiring admission for IV antibiotics. He also has a history of severe constipation. Which diagnostic test would be most appropriate to consider next?
questions.solution:
• Given the history of constipation and chest infection, this child may have cystic fibrosis.

Common presenting features of Cystic Fibrosis

  • Respiratory
    • Recurrent sinusitis
    • Recurrent pneumonia
    • Nasal polyp
    • Bronchiectasis
  • Gastro
    • Constipation, Delayed passage of meconium, Subacute obstruction
    • Fat soluble vitamin deficiency
  • Liver
    • Biliary cirrhosis
    • Gallstones
  • Pancreas
    • Malabsorption
    • Diabetes mellitus
  • Genital
    • Sterility in males
    • Low fertility in females

questions.text: You are treating a 10-month-old child with bronchiolitis. He has insignificant past history and born at term with no complications. What is the first line of management for the child?
questions.solution:
Management of infants with Bronchiolitis:

  • Supplemental oxygen is the mainstay
  • High flow nasal cannula for respiratory compromised patients
  • Inhaled Hypertonic saline- has some benefit
  • Heliox- useful in moderate to severe cases
  • Ribavirin- only for high-risk infants like CHD or chronic lung disease
  • Bronchodilators- no role
  • Corticosteroids- not recommended
  • Antibiotics- no role
  • RSV Ig (Palivizumab)- no role
  • Inhaled epinephrine and dexamethasone- limited role

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to you with stridor at rest, hoarse voice, barking cough and generally poor air entry. You call your senior for help. You prescribe a single dose of oral dexamethasone. What other treatment may you want to administer?
questions.solution:
The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine:

  • Moderate to severe stridor at rest
  • The possible need for intubation
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia

questions.text: A child is having inspiratory and expiratory stridor sounds. What is the likely region of narrowing in the respiratory tract?
Which of the following is the most common cause of Bronchiolitis in children?
questions.solution:
• Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is most common cause of Bronchiolitis.
  • Other causative organisms are
    • Parainfluenza virus
    • Adenovirus
    • Influenza viruses
    • pneumoniae (rare)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of aspirated foreign bodies in children?
questions.solution: • Right main bronchus is wider, straighter and more in line of main bronchus in comparison to left bronchus.

choices.text: Oral dexamethasone and admit for observation
Obtain IV access, or IO if unsuccessful, for IV ceftriaxone

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents in acute respiratory distress, with a harsh biphasic stridor. The child appears drowsy, with oxygen saturation around 90%. The parents give history of high-grade continuous fever since last 24 hours and noisy breathing since 6 hours. What is the most important next step?
questions.solution:
• Regardless of underlying diagnosis, this child has an unstable airway (stridor) with impending respiratory failure (drowsy and hypoxic) and needs urgent anesthetic input for a definitive airway.
  • The child is most likely suffering from Epiglottitis suggested by high fever, rapid deterioration and sick child with stridor appearing late.
  • Dexamethasone is contraindicated in epiglottitis.
  • Other steps mentioned are needed but not immediate.

questions.text: On examination, what is a 'Harrison Groove' indicative of?
questions.solution:
• A Harrison groove (or sulcus) is a horizontal depression along the lower border of the chest at diaphragm insertion site.
  • It represents chronic tachypnoea and may be present in certain congenital heart defects or respiratory conditions.

questions.text: Which vitamins need to be supplemented in CF patients?
questions.solution:
• Malabsorption is a known complication of cystic fibrosis causing decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
  • A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins and need supplementation in CF.

choices.text: Perform the Heimlich maneuver to dislodge foreign body
Order urgent bronchoscopy to remove foreign body
Start needle thoracocentesis for tension pneumothorax
Encourage the child to cough up foreign body

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the ED with shortness of breath in mild distress. His parents state that they were at a movie theater and eating popcorn yesterday evening when the child 'choked' on a bit of popcorn. He is slightly tachypneic and tachycardic but is saturating well on room air. You order a stat chest x-ray. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
• The chest x-ray shows hyperinflation of the left side and a mediastinal shift to the right, which should raise suspicion for a foreign body in the left bronchus. Hyperinflation is indicative of partial obstruction.
  • With a complete obstruction, there should be atelectasis on the affected side and a mediastinal shift to the affected side.
  • Heimlich maneuver is performed in upper airway obstruction.
  • There is no pneumothorax, hence no point of needle thoracocentesis.
  • Rigid bronchoscopy is diagnostic and therapeutic.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to you with parents complaining that the child has abnormal sounds while breathing in. it worsens on crying and improves when held prone. What is the most likely cause of infant's sound?
questions.solution:
• Commonest cause of stridor in an healthy infant.
  • It is due to soft larynx, that gets pulled during inspiration and thus producing whistling sound.
  • Typical characteristic is that the stridor is aggravated on exertion like crying, agitation and feeding and disappears in prone position.
  • It is self-resolving condition and needs no active management.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child who is previously diagnosed with Cystic fibrosis, comes with high fever and productive coughing in last 3 days. X ray shows unilateral consolidation. Which of the following organism is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
• Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas are the most common organisms responsible for pneumonia in patients with cystic fibrosis.
  • Staphylococcus aureus is more common in children; Pseudomonas is more common in adult.
  • Burkholderia can be one of the causes but it is less common.

questions.text: A 1-day-old infant in the nursery is found to have episodes of apnea and respiratory distress. The infant's oxygen saturations during rest are 75-85%, but when the infant cries, the oxygen saturations improve to 95-100%. During a bottle feed, the infant is fussy, becomes cyanotic, and noticeably chokes. The nurse is unable to pass a feeding tube down either naris. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• The infant in the vignette has bilateral choanal atresia, a congenital membranous or bony blockage of the posterior nasal choanae.
  • Unilateral choanal atresia is more common and usually presents with milder symptoms, such as sinusitis, later in life.
  • Bilateral choanal atresia, however, presents shortly after birth and is considered an airway emergency. Infants typically present with apnea, cyanosis, and respiratory distress, which is alleviated when the mouth is open and crying. The infants have difficulty feeding, and characteristically, caregivers are unable to pass a feeding tube down the nares.
  • Initial management involves inserting an oral airway, which may be a McGovern nipple, an endotracheal tube, or a laryngeal mask airway. A McGovern nipple is essentially a pacifier with a sizeable hole at the nipple end, which is then secured in the infant's mouth with ties around the occiput.
  • Choanal atresia may occur in isolation or as part of a multiple congenital anomaly syndrome, such as
  • Surgical repair involves transnasal stenting/puncture or endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy comes with respiratory distress and X ray suggestive of 5cm left sided pneumothorax. A chest drain is to be inserted. What is the anatomical landmark where the chest drain is to be inserted?
questions.solution: • The 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line is generally used for most situations. This area is commonly known as the 'safe triangle,' bordered by the anterior border of latissimus dorsi, the lateral border of the pectoralis major, a line superior to the horizontal level of the nipple and an apex below the axilla. The drain should be inserted just above the rib.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia. He has worsening respiratory distress. Which of the following sign will be seen latest?
questions.solution:
• Cyanosis is a sign of decompensation and is a sign of severe respiratory distress with impending respiratory failure.
  • Other signs appear earlier in the compensation phase.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of wheezing in child?
questions.solution:
• Wheezing occurs due to narrowing of larger airways.
  • Asthma and bronchiolitis affect bronchi and bronchioles.
  • Foreign body gets trapped in larger bronchi branches and can cause both stridor or wheeze.
  • Epiglottitis presents with acute stridor - which is a harsh respiratory sound produced by turbulent flow in narrow upper airways.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common adverse effect associated with inhaled corticosteroids in asthma patients?
questions.solution: • Patients using inhaled corticosteroids can get a fungal infection called oropharyngeal candidiasis. The infection occurs because the steroids weaken the immune system in the mouth and throat.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy have wet cough and runny nose since birth. He has speech delay, hearing problems and dextrocardia on the CXR. He was admitted with pneumonia as a neonate and has been prescribed antibiotics for chest infections on 5 occasions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Primary ciliary dyskinesia presents commonly with bronchiectasis, sinusitis, hearing difficulties and recurrent chest infections.

FINDINGS IN PCD:

RESPIRATORY TRACT

  • Lung
    • Neonatal respiratory distress
    • Chronic cough
    • Recurrent pneumonia
    • Bronchiectasis
  • Middle Ear
    • Chronic otitis media
    • Conductive hearing loss
  • Paranasal Sinuses
    • Neonatal rhinitis
    • Chronic mucopurulent rhinitis
    • Chronic pansinusitis
    • Nasal polyposis

GENITOURINARY TRACT

  • Male and female infertility

LEFT-RIGHT ORIENTATION DEFECTS

  • Situs inversus
  • Heterotaxy
  • Congenital heart disease

CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM

  • Hydrocephalus
  • Retinitis pigmentosa

questions.text: Which of the following is a known environmental risk factor for asthma?
questions.solution:
RISK FACTORS FOR ASTHMA IN CHILDHOOD

  • Parental asthma
  • Allergy:
    • Atopic dermatitis (eczema)
    • Allergic rhinitis
    • Food allergy
    • Inhalant allergen sensitization
    • Food allergen sensitization
  • Severe lower respiratory tract infection:
    • Pneumonia
    • Bronchiolitis requiring hospitalization
  • Wheezing apart from colds
  • Male gender
  • Low birthweight
  • Environmental tobacco smoke exposure
  • Reduced lung function at birth

Out of all this, only Smoking exposure is environmental factor

questions.text: In a child suffering from pneumonia, all the following are indications to admit the child, who was previously healthy, except
questions.solution:
INDICATIONS FOR ADMISSION

  • Poor oral intake
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Stridor at rest
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A 12-year-old child comes to you with complaints of wet cough since 4 days and high grade continuous fever since 3 days. The X ray chest is as shown. What is the most likely organism for the condition?
questions.solution:
• The X ray is suggestive of unilateral consolidation with cavitation. There are loculated necrosed tissues or cavitations. These along with acute history of high fever and wet cough are more likely to be seen in Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia.
  • It may develop complications like empyema, pneumatocele or bronchopulmonary fistula.

choices.text: Fall in FEV1 = 10% on exercise challenge test

questions.text: A 6-year-old child having repeated episodes of coughing and wheezing, is seen by a general physician in the peripheral center. The child has always responded to short course of bronchodilator. He is now referred to you for spirometry to confirm the diagnosis of Bronchial asthma. Which of the following spirometry finding in the child is not agreeing with the diagnosis of asthma?
questions.solution:
Updated criteria for diagnosis of Asthma in children

  • FEV1/FVC < 0.9
  • Diurnal variation of PEFR > 13%
  • Increase in FEV1 > 12% on giving bronchodilator
  • On exercise challenge test
    • Fall in FEV1 > 12%
    • Fall in PEFR > 15%

Reference: GINA guidelines, 2023, pg. 23

choices.text: Low dose inhalational corticosteroids (ICS) before exercise

questions.text: Which of the following is not the recommendation for management of exercise induced asthma?
questions.solution:
Breakthrough Exercise induced asthma can be managed with

  • Warm up before exercise
  • SABA before or during exercise
  • Low dose ICS formoterol before or during exercise

For prevention of Exercise induced bronchoconstriction

  • Daily treatment with ICS

Reference: GINA guidelines, 2023, pg. 91
